Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
One summer evening in 335 BCE, 
Alexander the Great was resting by the Danube River after 
a day of fighting the Scythian tribes when a band of strangers 
approached his camp. Alexander had never seen anything 
like these tall, fierce-looking warriors with huge 
golden neck rings and colorful cloaks— so he invited them to feast with him. They proudly said they were Keltoi 
or Celts who came from the far-away Alps. Alexander asked what they feared 
the most in the world, hoping they would say him. They laughed and said they feared 
nothing at all. This is one of the earliest stories 
about the ancient Celts. While we don’t know 
where the first Celts came from, by Alexander’s time 
they had spread across Europe from Asia Minor in the east to Spain and the Atlantic islands of Britain 
and Ireland in the west. The Celts were never one unified empire,
and they didn’t build cities or monuments. Instead, they were hundreds of independent
tribes who spoke the same language. Each had its own warrior-king 
and religious center. The tribes fought each other as enthusiastically as they fought 
their enemies. Few armies could stand up to them. Somewhat unusually for the time, 
the Celts believed in reincarnation— that they would be reborn on Earth 
to live and feast and fight again, which may have contributed 
to their fearlessness in battle. Some of them fought naked, 
scoffing at their enemies’ armor. The greatest trophy a Celtic warrior
could possess was the severed head of a foe. They preserved these heads 
in jars of cedar oil and showed them to guests 
who visited their homes. Celtic warriors were so valued 
in the ancient world that foreign kings often hired 
them as mercenary soldiers to serve in their armies. But the Celts were much more 
than just warriors. Among them were many skilled craftsmen,
artists, and great poets called bards. The bards sang of the brave deeds 
of their ancestors and praised the accomplishments
of warrior kings— and composed biting satires 
about cowardly or selfish leaders. The Celts worshipped many gods, and priests known as druids 
oversaw this worship. Anyone could become a druid, but the training required many years 
of study and memorization— the druids were not allowed to record
any of their teachings in writing. Druids supervised religious practices 
and sacrifices to the gods, but they were also teachers, healers, 
judges, and scientists. They were so respected that they could
step between warring tribes in the middle of a battle 
and call an end to the fighting. No Celt would dare to harm a druid,
or question their decisions. In the 2nd century BCE, the Romans 
began to encroach on Celtic territory, conquering the tribes of northern Italy. Rather than unite against the Roman 
legions in response to this defeat, the Celts maintained 
their tribal divisions. The tribes of Spain fell soon after. In the 1st century BCE, Julius Caesar 
marched his armies across France, using bribery, threats, and lies 
to turn tribes against each other. Only in the closing days of this great war did the Celts unite 
against their common enemy under the leadership 
of king Vercingetorix, but it was too late. Countless warriors and their families 
died or were enslaved as the Romans conquered France. Protected by the surrounding waters, the Celtic tribes of Britain and Ireland
were the last holdouts. When the Romans finally invaded Britain, the queen Boudicca united her tribe 
in a revolt after her husband was killed. She almost succeeded in driving 
the Roman legions out of Britain before dying as she led a final battle 
against the enemy. By the end of the 1st century CE, 
Ireland alone, far out at sea, remained unconquered by Rome. There, the ways of the ancient Celts 
survived untouched by the outside world long after Rome itself lay in ruins.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. warriors, B. bards, C. kings, D. children
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
One summer evening in 335 BCE, 
Alexander the Great was resting by the Danube River after 
a day of fighting the Scythian tribes when a band of strangers 
approached his camp. Alexander had never seen anything 
like these tall, fierce-looking warriors with huge 
golden neck rings and colorful cloaks— so he invited them to feast with him. They proudly said they were Keltoi 
or Celts who came from the far-away Alps. Alexander asked what they feared 
the most in the world, hoping they would say him. They laughed and said they feared 
nothing at all. This is one of the earliest stories 
about the ancient Celts. While we don’t know 
where the first Celts came from, by Alexander’s time 
they had spread across Europe from Asia Minor in the east to Spain and the Atlantic islands of Britain 
and Ireland in the west. The Celts were never one unified empire,
and they didn’t build cities or monuments. Instead, they were hundreds of independent
tribes who spoke the same language. Each had its own warrior-king 
and religious center. The tribes fought each other as enthusiastically as they fought 
their enemies. Few armies could stand up to them. Somewhat unusually for the time, 
the Celts believed in reincarnation— that they would be reborn on Earth 
to live and feast and fight again, which may have contributed 
to their fearlessness in battle. Some of them fought naked, 
scoffing at their enemies’ armor. The greatest trophy a Celtic warrior
could possess was the severed head of a foe. They preserved these heads 
in jars of cedar oil and showed them to guests 
who visited their homes. Celtic warriors were so valued 
in the ancient world that foreign kings often hired 
them as mercenary soldiers to serve in their armies. But the Celts were much more 
than just warriors. Among them were many skilled craftsmen,
artists, and great poets called bards. The bards sang of the brave deeds 
of their ancestors and praised the accomplishments
of warrior kings— and composed biting satires 
about cowardly or selfish leaders. The Celts worshipped many gods, and priests known as druids 
oversaw this worship. Anyone could become a druid, but the training required many years 
of study and memorization— the druids were not allowed to record
any of their teachings in writing. Druids supervised religious practices 
and sacrifices to the gods, but they were also teachers, healers, 
judges, and scientists. They were so respected that they could
step between warring tribes in the middle of a battle 
and call an end to the fighting. No Celt would dare to harm a druid,
or question their decisions. In the 2nd century BCE, the Romans 
began to encroach on Celtic territory, conquering the tribes of northern Italy. Rather than unite against the Roman 
legions in response to this defeat, the Celts maintained 
their tribal divisions. The tribes of Spain fell soon after. In the 1st century BCE, Julius Caesar 
marched his armies across France, using bribery, threats, and lies 
to turn tribes against each other. Only in the closing days of this great war did the Celts unite 
against their common enemy under the leadership 
of king Vercingetorix, but it was too late. Countless warriors and their families 
died or were enslaved as the Romans conquered France. Protected by the surrounding waters, the Celtic tribes of Britain and Ireland
were the last holdouts. When the Romans finally invaded Britain, the queen Boudicca united her tribe 
in a revolt after her husband was killed. She almost succeeded in driving 
the Roman legions out of Britain before dying as she led a final battle 
against the enemy. By the end of the 1st century CE, 
Ireland alone, far out at sea, remained unconquered by Rome. There, the ways of the ancient Celts 
survived untouched by the outside world long after Rome itself lay in ruins.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Priests known as ______ oversaw the Celts' worship of many gods
Options: A. bards, B. celtic monks, C. Keltoi, D. Druids
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where did Alexander the Great first encounter the Celts in 335 BCE? Options: A. By the Rhine River, B. In the Alps, C. By the Danube River, D. In Britain Correct Option: C
Question 2: What distinctive aspect of the Celts' belief system set them apart from other cultures of their time? Options: A. They believed in a single, all-powerful god, B. They believed in a strict social hierarchy, C. They believed in the importance of building cities, D. They believed in reincarnation Correct Option: D
Question 3: What significance did a Celtic warrior's possession of a severed head hold? Options: A. It symbolized their wealth and status, B. It represented their spiritual connection to the gods, C. It was a reminder of their enemies' weakness, D. It was a trophy that showcased their bravery and strength Correct Option: D
Question 4: What roles did druids play in Celtic society? Options: A. They were solely responsible for leading battles and wars, B. They were only involved in religious practices and sacrifices, C. They were teachers, healers, judges, and scientists who oversaw religious practices and sacrifices, D. They were only responsible for composing poetry and music Correct Option: C
Question 5: What tactic did the Romans use to ultimately conquer the Celts in France? Options: A. Through a series of brutal battles and massacres, B. By forming alliances with other Celtic tribes, C. By imposing economic sanctions and trade embargoes, D. By using bribery, threats, and lies to turn tribes against each other Correct Option: D
Question 6: Who led the Celtic revolt against the Romans in Britain? Options: A. King Vercingetorix, B. Queen Boudicca, C. Alexander the Great, D. Julius Caesar Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the outcome of the Roman invasion of Britain? Options: A. The Celts emerged victorious and drove the Romans out, B. The Romans conquered Britain, but the Celts maintained their independence, C. The Romans conquered Britain, and many Celts were killed or enslaved, D. The invasion was repelled, and the Romans never returned Correct Option: C
Question 8: Why did the Celts' tribal divisions make them vulnerable to Roman conquest? Options: A. Because they were unable to unite against a common enemy, B. Because they were too focused on their own internal conflicts, C. Because they lacked a unified leadership, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What were the consequences of the Celts' tribal divisions in the face of Roman conquest? Options: A. They were able to unite and defeat the Romans, B. They were too focused on their own internal conflicts to respond effectively, C. They lacked a unified leadership to coordinate a defense, D. They were unable to unite against a common enemy, leading to their eventual defeat Correct Option: D
Question 10: What factors contributed to the Celts' vulnerability to Roman conquest? Options: A. Their inability to unite against a common enemy, B. Their geographical dispersion and lack of unified leadership, C. Their focus on internal conflicts, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 11: What combination of factors made the Celts vulnerable to Roman conquest? Options: A. Their inability to unite against a common enemy and geographical dispersion, B. Their lack of unified leadership and focus on internal conflicts, C. Their military tactics and economic systems, D. All of the above, including their inability to unite, geographical dispersion, lack of unified leadership, and focus on internal conflicts Correct Option: D
Question 12: How did the Celts' cultural practices and traditions survive in the face of Roman conquest? Options: A. Through their written records and historical accounts, B. Through their oral traditions and storytelling, C. Through their art and architecture, D. Through their isolation in Ireland Correct Option: D
Question 13: What can be inferred about the Celts' values and priorities based on their cultural practices and traditions? Options: A. They valued material wealth and power above all else, B. They prioritized individual freedom and autonomy, C. They emphasized the importance of community, honor, and loyalty, D. They were primarily focused on military conquest and expansion Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Although the question is not an exact match, the correct option (C) mentions that druids "oversaw religious practices and sacrifices," which aligns with the ground truth MCQ. The other options in Question 4 do not directly address the oversight of worship, but the question's intent and correct option's content are the most similar to the ground truth MCQ among the provided generated MCQs.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
One summer evening in 335 BCE, 
Alexander the Great was resting by the Danube River after 
a day of fighting the Scythian tribes when a band of strangers 
approached his camp. Alexander had never seen anything 
like these tall, fierce-looking warriors with huge 
golden neck rings and colorful cloaks— so he invited them to feast with him. They proudly said they were Keltoi 
or Celts who came from the far-away Alps. Alexander asked what they feared 
the most in the world, hoping they would say him. They laughed and said they feared 
nothing at all. This is one of the earliest stories 
about the ancient Celts. While we don’t know 
where the first Celts came from, by Alexander’s time 
they had spread across Europe from Asia Minor in the east to Spain and the Atlantic islands of Britain 
and Ireland in the west. The Celts were never one unified empire,
and they didn’t build cities or monuments. Instead, they were hundreds of independent
tribes who spoke the same language. Each had its own warrior-king 
and religious center. The tribes fought each other as enthusiastically as they fought 
their enemies. Few armies could stand up to them. Somewhat unusually for the time, 
the Celts believed in reincarnation— that they would be reborn on Earth 
to live and feast and fight again, which may have contributed 
to their fearlessness in battle. Some of them fought naked, 
scoffing at their enemies’ armor. The greatest trophy a Celtic warrior
could possess was the severed head of a foe. They preserved these heads 
in jars of cedar oil and showed them to guests 
who visited their homes. Celtic warriors were so valued 
in the ancient world that foreign kings often hired 
them as mercenary soldiers to serve in their armies. But the Celts were much more 
than just warriors. Among them were many skilled craftsmen,
artists, and great poets called bards. The bards sang of the brave deeds 
of their ancestors and praised the accomplishments
of warrior kings— and composed biting satires 
about cowardly or selfish leaders. The Celts worshipped many gods, and priests known as druids 
oversaw this worship. Anyone could become a druid, but the training required many years 
of study and memorization— the druids were not allowed to record
any of their teachings in writing. Druids supervised religious practices 
and sacrifices to the gods, but they were also teachers, healers, 
judges, and scientists. They were so respected that they could
step between warring tribes in the middle of a battle 
and call an end to the fighting. No Celt would dare to harm a druid,
or question their decisions. In the 2nd century BCE, the Romans 
began to encroach on Celtic territory, conquering the tribes of northern Italy. Rather than unite against the Roman 
legions in response to this defeat, the Celts maintained 
their tribal divisions. The tribes of Spain fell soon after. In the 1st century BCE, Julius Caesar 
marched his armies across France, using bribery, threats, and lies 
to turn tribes against each other. Only in the closing days of this great war did the Celts unite 
against their common enemy under the leadership 
of king Vercingetorix, but it was too late. Countless warriors and their families 
died or were enslaved as the Romans conquered France. Protected by the surrounding waters, the Celtic tribes of Britain and Ireland
were the last holdouts. When the Romans finally invaded Britain, the queen Boudicca united her tribe 
in a revolt after her husband was killed. She almost succeeded in driving 
the Roman legions out of Britain before dying as she led a final battle 
against the enemy. By the end of the 1st century CE, 
Ireland alone, far out at sea, remained unconquered by Rome. There, the ways of the ancient Celts 
survived untouched by the outside world long after Rome itself lay in ruins.

Correct Option: C

Question 9: What were the consequences of the Celts' tribal divisions in the face of Roman conquest? Options: A. They were able to unite and defeat the Romans, B. They were too focused on their own internal conflicts to respond effectively, C. They lacked a unified leadership to coordinate a defense, D. They were unable to unite against a common enemy, leading to their eventual defeat Correct Option: D
Question 10: What factors contributed to the Celts' vulnerability to Roman conquest? Options: A. Their inability to unite against a common enemy, B. Their geographical dispersion and lack of unified leadership, C. Their focus on internal conflicts, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 11: What combination of factors made the Celts vulnerable to Roman conquest? Options: A. Their inability to unite against a common enemy and geographical dispersion, B. Their lack of unified leadership and focus on internal conflicts, C. Their military tactics and economic systems, D. All of the above, including their inability to unite, geographical dispersion, lack of unified leadership, and focus on internal conflicts Correct Option: D
Question 12: How did the Celts' cultural practices and traditions survive in the face of Roman conquest? Options: A. Through their written records and historical accounts, B. Through their oral traditions and storytelling, C. Through their art and architecture, D. Through their isolation in Ireland Correct Option: D
Question 13: What can be inferred about the Celts' values and priorities based on their cultural practices and traditions? Options: A. They valued material wealth and power above all else, B. They prioritized individual freedom and autonomy, C. They emphasized the importance of community, honor, and loyalty, D. They were primarily focused on military conquest and expansion Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 12. 

This question asks how the Celts' cultural practices and traditions survived in the face of Roman conquest, with the correct answer being "Through their isolation in Ireland." This matches the intent and content of the ground truth MCQ, which asks what part of the Celtic world was not conquered by the Romans, with the correct answer being "Ireland." 

While the wording and focus of the two questions differ slightly, they both address the same underlying topic and have the same geographical area as the correct answer.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was a feast like Egypt 
had never seen before. The warrior god Set and his wife, 
the goddess Nephtys, decorated an extravagant hall 
for the occasion, with a beautiful wooden chest 
as the centerpiece. They invited all the most important gods,
dozens of lesser deities, and foreign monarchs. But no one caused as big a stir as Set 
and Nephtys’s older brother Osiris, the god who ruled all of Egypt 
and had brought prosperity to everyone. Set announced a game— whoever could fit perfectly in the chest
could have it as a gift. One by one, the guests clambered in,
but no one fit. Finally, it was Osiris’s turn. As he lay down, everyone could see
it was a perfect fit— another win for the god 
who could do no wrong. Then Set slammed the lid down 
with Osiris still inside, sealed it shut, and tossed it into the Nile. The chest was a coffin. Set had constructed it specifically 
to trap his brother and planned the party to lure him into it. Set had long been jealous 
of his brother’s successful reign, and hoped to replace 
him as the ruler of all Egypt. The Nile bore the coffin out to sea 
and it drifted for many days before washing ashore near Byblos, 
where a great cedar grew around it. The essence of the god within 
gave the tree a divine aura, and when the king of Byblos noticed it, he ordered the tree cut down
and brought to his palace. Unbeknownst to him, the coffin containing Egypt’s 
most powerful god was still inside. Set’s victory seemed complete, 
but he hadn’t counted on his sisters. Set’s wife Nephtys was also his sister, while their other sister, 
the goddess Isis, was married to their brother Osiris. Isis was determined to find Osiris, and enlisted Nephtys’s help 
behind Set’s back. The two sisters took the shape 
of falcons and travelled far and wide. Some children who had seen 
the coffin float by pointed them to the palace of Byblos. Isis adopted a new disguise 
and approached the palace. The queen was so charmed 
by the disguised goddess that she entrusted her 
with nursing the baby prince. Isis decided to make the child immortal 
by bathing him in flame. When the horrified queen 
came upon this scene, Isis revealed herself 
and demanded the tree. When she cut the coffin from the trunk
and opened it, Osiris was dead inside. Weeping, she carried his body 
back to Egypt and hid it in a swamp, while she set off in search 
of a means of resurrecting him. But while she was gone, Set found the body 
and cut it into many pieces, scattering them throughout Egypt. Isis had lost Osiris for the second time,
but she did not give up. She searched all over the land,
traveling in a boat of papyrus. One by one, she tracked down 
the parts of her husband’s dismembered body
in every province of Egypt, holding a funeral for each piece. At long last, she had recovered
every piece but one— his penis, 
which a fish in the Nile had eaten. Working with what she had, Isis 
reconstructed and revived her husband. But without his penis, 
Osiris was incomplete. He could not remain among the living, could not return to his old position 
as ruler of Egypt. Instead, he would have to rule over Duat,
the realm of the dead. Before he went, though, he and Isis 
conceived a son to bear Osiris’s legacy— and one day, avenge him.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was Set the god of...
Options: A. Warfare, B. The underworld, C. The harvest
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was the god that ruled all of Egypt and had brought prosperity to everyone? Options: A. Set, B. Osiris, C. Isis, D. Nephtys Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the true purpose of the beautiful wooden chest at the party hosted by Set and Nephtys? Options: A. A gift for the guests, B. A coffin to trap Osiris, C. A symbol of their wealth and status, D. A decoration for the hall Correct Option: B
Question 3: If you were a guest at the party, how would you have likely felt when you saw the chest and were invited to try to fit inside? Options: A. Suspicious and cautious, B. Excited and eager to win the gift, C. Indifferent and uninterested, D. Angry and resentful Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the significance of the cedar tree that grew around the coffin in Byblos? Options: A. It was a symbol of the power of the king of Byblos, B. It was a sign of the divine aura of the god within the coffin, C. It was a natural wonder of the ancient world, D. It marked the final resting place of Osiris Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why did Isis decide to make the baby prince of Byblos immortal by bathing him in flame? Options: A. To test the queen's trust in her, B. To demonstrate her divine power, C. To ensure the child's safety and well-being, D. To gain the queen's favor and assistance Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the result of Set's actions when he cut Osiris's body into many pieces and scattered them throughout Egypt? Options: A. Osiris was resurrected and returned to his old position as ruler of Egypt, B. Isis was able to recover all the pieces and revive Osiris, but he was incomplete, C. Osiris was incomplete and had to rule over Duat, the realm of the dead, D. Set became the new ruler of Egypt Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did Isis ultimately recover the pieces of Osiris's dismembered body? Options: A. She used her divine powers to locate them, B. She enlisted the help of other gods and goddesses, C. She traveled in a boat of papyrus and searched every province of Egypt, D. She followed the trail of clues left by Set Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the significance of the fact that a fish in the Nile had eaten Osiris's penis? Options: A. It was a symbol of the power of the Nile, B. It was a reminder of the impermanence of life, C. It meant that Osiris could not remain among the living or return to his old position as ruler of Egypt, D. It prevented Osiris from being resurrected Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the outcome of Osiris's resurrection, and what role did he take on after his revival? Options: A. He returned to his old position as ruler of Egypt and lived happily ever after, B. He became the ruler of Duat, the realm of the dead, and was revered as a god, C. He was reborn as a mortal and lived a new life, D. He was given a new role as a god, but with limited powers Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the broader significance of the story of Osiris and Isis in ancient Egyptian mythology? Options: A. It explains the creation of the world and the origin of the gods, B. It justifies the rule of the pharaohs and the social hierarchy of ancient Egypt, C. It provides a moral lesson about the dangers of jealousy and ambition, D. It describes the cyclical nature of life and death and the importance of resurrection and rebirth Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

The ground truth MCQ asks about Set's role as a god, specifically what he is the god of. The most similar generated MCQ is Question 1, which asks about the god that ruled all of Egypt and had brought prosperity to everyone. Although this question is not directly related to Set's role, it does mention Set as an option, and the correct answer is Osiris, who is Set's brother and the ruler of Egypt.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 2

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
It was a feast like Egypt 
had never seen before. The warrior god Set and his wife, 
the goddess Nephtys, decorated an extravagant hall 
for the occasion, with a beautiful wooden chest 
as the centerpiece. They invited all the most important gods,
dozens of lesser deities, and foreign monarchs. But no one caused as big a stir as Set 
and Nephtys’s older brother Osiris, the god who ruled all of Egypt 
and had brought prosperity to everyone. Set announced a game— whoever could fit perfectly in the chest
could have it as a gift. One by one, the guests clambered in,
but no one fit. Finally, it was Osiris’s turn. As he lay down, everyone could see
it was a perfect fit— another win for the god 
who could do no wrong. Then Set slammed the lid down 
with Osiris still inside, sealed it shut, and tossed it into the Nile. The chest was a coffin. Set had constructed it specifically 
to trap his brother and planned the party to lure him into it. Set had long been jealous 
of his brother’s successful reign, and hoped to replace 
him as the ruler of all Egypt. The Nile bore the coffin out to sea 
and it drifted for many days before washing ashore near Byblos, 
where a great cedar grew around it. The essence of the god within 
gave the tree a divine aura, and when the king of Byblos noticed it, he ordered the tree cut down
and brought to his palace. Unbeknownst to him, the coffin containing Egypt’s 
most powerful god was still inside. Set’s victory seemed complete, 
but he hadn’t counted on his sisters. Set’s wife Nephtys was also his sister, while their other sister, 
the goddess Isis, was married to their brother Osiris. Isis was determined to find Osiris, and enlisted Nephtys’s help 
behind Set’s back. The two sisters took the shape 
of falcons and travelled far and wide. Some children who had seen 
the coffin float by pointed them to the palace of Byblos. Isis adopted a new disguise 
and approached the palace. The queen was so charmed 
by the disguised goddess that she entrusted her 
with nursing the baby prince. Isis decided to make the child immortal 
by bathing him in flame. When the horrified queen 
came upon this scene, Isis revealed herself 
and demanded the tree. When she cut the coffin from the trunk
and opened it, Osiris was dead inside. Weeping, she carried his body 
back to Egypt and hid it in a swamp, while she set off in search 
of a means of resurrecting him. But while she was gone, Set found the body 
and cut it into many pieces, scattering them throughout Egypt. Isis had lost Osiris for the second time,
but she did not give up. She searched all over the land,
traveling in a boat of papyrus. One by one, she tracked down 
the parts of her husband’s dismembered body
in every province of Egypt, holding a funeral for each piece. At long last, she had recovered
every piece but one— his penis, 
which a fish in the Nile had eaten. Working with what she had, Isis 
reconstructed and revived her husband. But without his penis, 
Osiris was incomplete. He could not remain among the living, could not return to his old position 
as ruler of Egypt. Instead, he would have to rule over Duat,
the realm of the dead. Before he went, though, he and Isis 
conceived a son to bear Osiris’s legacy— and one day, avenge him.

It was a feast like Egypt 
had never seen before. The warrior god Set and his wife, 
the goddess Nephtys, decorated an extravagant hall 
for the occasion, with a beautiful wooden chest 
as the centerpiece. They invited all the most important gods,
dozens of lesser deities, and foreign monarchs. But no one caused as big a stir as Set

and had brought prosperity to everyone. Set announced a game— whoever could fit perfectly in the chest
could have it as a gift. One by one, the guests clambered in,

who could do no wrong. Then Set slammed the lid down

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:
It was a feast like Egypt 
had never seen before. The warrior god Set and his wife, 
the goddess Nephtys, decorated an extravagant hall 
for the occasion, with a beautiful wooden chest 
as the centerpiece. They invited all the most important gods,
dozens of lesser deities, and foreign monarchs. But no one caused as big a stir as Set 
and Nephtys’s older brother Osiris, the god who ruled all of Egypt 
and had brought prosperity to everyone. Set announced a game— whoever could fit perfectly in the chest
could have it as a gift. One by one, the guests clambered in,
but no one fit. Finally, it was Osiris’s turn. As he lay down, everyone could see
it was a perfect fit— another win for the god 
who could do no wrong. Then Set slammed the lid down 
with Osiris still inside, sealed it shut, and tossed it into the Nile. The chest was a coffin. Set had constructed it specifically 
to trap his brother and planned the party to lure him into it. Set had long been jealous 
of his brother’s successful reign, and hoped to replace 
him as the ruler of all Egypt. The Nile bore the coffin out to sea 
and it drifted for many days before washing ashore near Byblos, 
where a great cedar grew around it. The essence of the god within 
gave the tree a divine aura, and when the king of Byblos noticed it, he ordered the tree cut down
and brought to his palace. Unbeknownst to him, the coffin containing Egypt’s 
most powerful god was still inside. Set’s victory seemed complete, 
but he hadn’t counted on his sisters. Set’s wife Nephtys was also his sister, while their other sister, 
the goddess Isis, was married to their brother Osiris. Isis was determined to find Osiris, and enlisted Nephtys’s help 
behind Set’s back. The two sisters took the shape 
of falcons and travelled far and wide. Some children who had seen 
the coffin float by pointed them to the palace of Byblos. Isis adopted a new disguise 
and approached the palace. The queen was so charmed 
by the disguised goddess that she entrusted her 
with nursing the baby prince. Isis decided to make the child immortal 
by bathing him in flame. When the horrified queen 
came upon this scene, Isis revealed herself 
and demanded the tree. When she cut the coffin from the trunk
and opened it, Osiris was dead inside. Weeping, she carried his body 
back to Egypt and hid it in a swamp, while she set off in search 
of a means of resurrecting him. But while she was gone, Set found the body 
and cut it into many pieces, scattering them throughout Egypt. Isis had lost Osiris for the second time,
but she did not give up. She searched all over the land,
traveling in a boat of papyrus. One by one, she tracked down 
the parts of her husband’s dismembered body
in every province of Egypt, holding a funeral for each piece. At long last, she had recovered
every piece but one— his penis, 
which a fish in the Nile had eaten. Working with what she had, Isis 
reconstructed and revived her husband. But without his penis, 
Osiris was incomplete. He could not remain among the living, could not return to his old position 
as ruler of Egypt. Instead, he would have to rule over Duat,
the realm of the dead. Before he went, though, he and Isis 
conceived a son to bear Osiris’s legacy— and one day, avenge him.

Question 3: If you were a guest at the party, how would you have likely felt when you saw the chest and were invited to try to fit inside? Options: A. Suspicious and cautious, B. Excited and eager to win the gift, C. Indifferent and uninterested, D. Angry and resentful Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the significance of the cedar tree that grew around the coffin in Byblos? Options: A. It was a symbol of the power of the king of Byblos, B. It was a sign of the divine aura of the god within the coffin, C. It was a natural wonder of the ancient world, D. It marked the final resting place of Osiris Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why did Isis decide to make the baby prince of Byblos immortal by bathing him in flame? Options: A. To test the queen's trust in her, B. To demonstrate her divine power, C. To ensure the child's safety and well-being, D. To gain the queen's favor and assistance Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the result of Set's actions when he cut Osiris's body into many pieces and scattered them throughout Egypt? Options: A. Osiris was resurrected and returned to his old position as ruler of Egypt, B. Isis was able to recover all the pieces and revive Osiris, but he was incomplete, C. Osiris was incomplete and had to rule over Duat, the realm of the dead, D. Set became the new ruler of Egypt Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did Isis ultimately recover the pieces of Osiris's dismembered body? Options: A. She used her divine powers to locate them, B. She enlisted the help of other gods and goddesses, C. She traveled in a boat of papyrus and searched every province of Egypt, D. She followed the trail of clues left by Set Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the significance of the fact that a fish in the Nile had eaten Osiris's penis? Options: A. It was a symbol of the power of the Nile, B. It was a reminder of the impermanence of life, C. It meant that Osiris could not remain among the living or return to his old position as ruler of Egypt, D. It prevented Osiris from being resurrected Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the outcome of Osiris's resurrection, and what role did he take on after his revival? Options: A. He returned to his old position as ruler of Egypt and lived happily ever after, B. He became the ruler of Duat, the realm of the dead, and was revered as a god, C. He was reborn as a mortal and lived a new life, D. He was given a new role as a god, but with limited powers Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the broader significance of the story of Osiris and Isis in ancient Egyptian mythology? Options: A. It explains the creation of the world and the origin of the gods, B. It justifies the rule of the pharaohs and the social hierarchy of ancient Egypt, C. It provides a moral lesson about the dangers of jealousy and ambition, D. It describes the cyclical nature of life and death and the importance of resurrection and rebirth Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 4: What was the significance of the cedar tree that grew around the coffin in Byblos?**

Although this question does not directly ask where Isis found Osiris's body, it is related to the location (Byblos) and the context (the cedar tree growing around the coffin) where the body was found.

However, a more direct match would be a question that specifically asks about the location where Isis found Osiris's body. Unfortunately, such a question is not present in the provided generated MCQs.

If I had to choose the most similar question based on the given options, I would choose **Question 4** as it is the closest match in terms of context and location.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was a feast like Egypt 
had never seen before. The warrior god Set and his wife, 
the goddess Nephtys, decorated an extravagant hall 
for the occasion, with a beautiful wooden chest 
as the centerpiece. They invited all the most important gods,
dozens of lesser deities, and foreign monarchs. But no one caused as big a stir as Set 
and Nephtys’s older brother Osiris, the god who ruled all of Egypt 
and had brought prosperity to everyone. Set announced a game— whoever could fit perfectly in the chest
could have it as a gift. One by one, the guests clambered in,
but no one fit. Finally, it was Osiris’s turn. As he lay down, everyone could see
it was a perfect fit— another win for the god 
who could do no wrong. Then Set slammed the lid down 
with Osiris still inside, sealed it shut, and tossed it into the Nile. The chest was a coffin. Set had constructed it specifically 
to trap his brother and planned the party to lure him into it. Set had long been jealous 
of his brother’s successful reign, and hoped to replace 
him as the ruler of all Egypt. The Nile bore the coffin out to sea 
and it drifted for many days before washing ashore near Byblos, 
where a great cedar grew around it. The essence of the god within 
gave the tree a divine aura, and when the king of Byblos noticed it, he ordered the tree cut down
and brought to his palace. Unbeknownst to him, the coffin containing Egypt’s 
most powerful god was still inside. Set’s victory seemed complete, 
but he hadn’t counted on his sisters. Set’s wife Nephtys was also his sister, while their other sister, 
the goddess Isis, was married to their brother Osiris. Isis was determined to find Osiris, and enlisted Nephtys’s help 
behind Set’s back. The two sisters took the shape 
of falcons and travelled far and wide. Some children who had seen 
the coffin float by pointed them to the palace of Byblos. Isis adopted a new disguise 
and approached the palace. The queen was so charmed 
by the disguised goddess that she entrusted her 
with nursing the baby prince. Isis decided to make the child immortal 
by bathing him in flame. When the horrified queen 
came upon this scene, Isis revealed herself 
and demanded the tree. When she cut the coffin from the trunk
and opened it, Osiris was dead inside. Weeping, she carried his body 
back to Egypt and hid it in a swamp, while she set off in search 
of a means of resurrecting him. But while she was gone, Set found the body 
and cut it into many pieces, scattering them throughout Egypt. Isis had lost Osiris for the second time,
but she did not give up. She searched all over the land,
traveling in a boat of papyrus. One by one, she tracked down 
the parts of her husband’s dismembered body
in every province of Egypt, holding a funeral for each piece. At long last, she had recovered
every piece but one— his penis, 
which a fish in the Nile had eaten. Working with what she had, Isis 
reconstructed and revived her husband. But without his penis, 
Osiris was incomplete. He could not remain among the living, could not return to his old position 
as ruler of Egypt. Instead, he would have to rule over Duat,
the realm of the dead. Before he went, though, he and Isis 
conceived a son to bear Osiris’s legacy— and one day, avenge him.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How did Isis disguise herself?
Options: A. As a nursemaid, B. As a bird, C. As a fish
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the sun-dappled streets 
of a small town, a proud mother 
showed off her newborn son. Upon noticing his lucky birthmark, townsfolk predicted 
he would marry a princess. But soon, these rumors reached the ears 
of the wicked king. Enraged, the king stole the child away, 
and sent him hurtling down the river. But the infant’s luck proved greater 
than the king’s plan. Years later, the king 
was traveling his realm, when he spotted a strapping young man 
with an uncanny birthmark. After confirming the child’s origins, the sly king entrusted the boy 
with a letter for the queen. The youth eagerly set out 
to deliver the message— not knowing he was carrying 
his own death sentence. That night, roaming bandits 
stumbled upon his camp. Yet when they read the brutal letter, 
they were filled with pity. Deciding to make trouble for the king 
instead, they scribbled a new note. As soon as the youth 
arrived at the palace, he locked eyes with the princess. The two felt destined for each other. And when the queen read 
that the king approved this union, she joyfully organized 
a whirlwind wedding. When the king returned, 
he was furious. But he couldn’t execute his daughter’s 
beloved without reason. So he devised a diabolical trial. He ordered the youth 
to travel to Hell itself, and return with three golden hairs 
freshly plucked from the Devil’s head. Only upon succeeding 
could he return to his bride. The youth searched across the land 
for the entrance to Hell, until he finally reached 
an eerie village. Here, he saw some villagers 
gathered around a well. They closed in on the youth, 
refusing to let him pass until he answered their question: 
why was the well dry? The youth replied, 
“I will answer when I return.” They directed him further into town, where he came across another set 
of villagers contemplating a gnarled tree. They refused to let him pass 
until he answered their question: why was the tree barren? Again, the youth responded, 
“I will answer when I return." These villagers guided him to the dock, 
where an elderly ferryman awaited. As he paddled through the black water, 
the ferryman rasped a third question: how can I escape my interminable task? Once more, the youth promised, 
“I will answer when I return.” At last, they reached a hut sinking 
into the swampy banks of Hell. Reluctantly, the youth knocked 
on the rotting door. The devil’s grandmother 
answered his call. She was known to help some visiting souls,
and harm others. The youth had just finished his story 
when they heard the devil’s footsteps. Without warning, 
the boy’s world appeared to shrink. The devil’s grandmother lifted him 
into the folds of her sleeve, and welcomed her grandson. The old woman set to work, 
lavishing the devil with food and drink. When he fell asleep, she deftly plucked 
three gleaming hairs from his head. With each plucked hair, the Devil briefly 
awoke and complained about his dreams, full of nearby villagers 
and their problems. The next morning, the youth departed— armed with three golden hairs, 
and three pieces of information. He shared the devil’s first dream 
with the ferryman. If the boatman could hand his oars 
to a willing passenger, he would be free from his task. Back at the village, the youth declared 
that there was a mouse gnawing at the root of the tree, 
and an enormous toad blocking the well. The villagers rewarded him handsomely 
for his help. Back from his journey, the youth thrust 
the devil’s hairs at the king— but his greedy father-in-law 
only had eyes for the gold. The sly youth told the king 
that even greater wealth awaited him across the river. Immediately, the king 
hastened to the riverbank. Eager to claim his riches, he held out his hands impatiently 
to the grinning ferryman— who happily handed over his oars.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Devil’s Grandmother helped the youth by transforming into a
Options: A. Bat, B. Teacup, C. Black ant, D. Spider
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What prediction did the townsfolk make about the newborn son's future when they saw his lucky birthmark? Options: A. He would become a great king., B. He would marry a princess., C. He would be very wealthy., D. He would have a short life. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the king's true intention when he entrusted the youth with a letter for the queen? Options: A. To inform the queen about the youth's origins., B. To ask the queen to arrange a wedding for the youth., C. To order the queen to execute the youth., D. To trick the youth into carrying his own death sentence. Correct Option: D
Question 3: How did the youth ultimately respond to the king's order to travel to Hell and return with three golden hairs from the Devil's head? Options: A. He refused to go and tried to negotiate with the king., B. He immediately traveled to Hell without any preparation., C. He set out to gather information and resources before embarking on the journey., D. The youth accepted the challenge and successfully completed the task with the help of the devil's grandmother. Correct Option: D
Question 4: What can be inferred about the devil's grandmother based on her actions in the story? Options: A. She is cruel and helps no one., B. She is kind and helps everyone., C. She is selective about who she helps and has her own motivations., D. She is unaware of the youth's intentions. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What purpose do the villagers serve in the youth's journey? Options: A. They provide the youth with material wealth and rewards., B. They serve as obstacles for the youth to overcome., C. They offer the youth guidance and advice., D. They pose questions that the youth must answer, leading him to gain knowledge and insight that ultimately helps him solve their problems. Correct Option: D
Question 6: How does the youth's response to the villagers' questions demonstrate his problem-solving skills? Options: A. He provides immediate answers to their questions., B. He refuses to answer their questions., C. He promises to answer their questions when he returns, showing that he is able to delay gratification and prioritize his goals., D. He asks for more information before answering their questions. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the significance of the devil's dreams in the story? Options: A. They serve as a distraction from the main plot., B. They provide insight into the devil's character., C. They offer solutions to the problems posed by the villagers., D. They have no impact on the story. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What motivates the king, and what are his strengths and weaknesses? Options: A. The king is motivated by a desire to protect his daughter and is a fair ruler., B. The king is motivated by greed and a desire for power, and is cunning but also impulsive and gullible., C. The king is motivated by a desire for justice and is a wise ruler., D. The king is motivated by a desire for revenge and is a ruthless ruler. Correct Option: B
Question 9: How does the youth's journey to Hell and back affect his character development? Options: A. The journey has no impact on the youth's character., B. The journey teaches the youth about the importance of wealth and power., C. The journey helps the youth develop problem-solving skills, gain confidence, and outwit his enemies., D. The journey serves as a test of the youth's courage and bravery. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What message do you think the story conveys about the nature of power and authority? Options: A. That those in power are always just and fair., B. That power and authority can be used for good or evil, and that individuals must be mindful of their actions., C. That those in power are always corrupt and abusive., D. That power and authority are irrelevant to individual success. Correct Option: B
Question 11: What was the ultimate fate of the king in the story? Options: A. He was punished for his cruel deeds., B. He was rewarded for his kindness., C. He was tricked by the youth and the ferryman, and ended up taking the ferryman's place as a result of his own greed., D. He remained in power and continued to rule with an iron fist. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent.

However, I can suggest that the generated MCQ that comes closest to matching the ground truth MCQ is Question 4: "What can be inferred about the devil's grandmother based on her actions in the story?"

This question is related to the ground truth MCQ in that it involves the devil's grandmother, but it does not specifically ask about her transformation. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs directly address the transformation of the devil's grandmother.

If I had to choose an index, I would say that Question 4 (index 4) is the most similar generated MCQ, although it is not a direct match.

**Transcript**:
In the sun-dappled streets 
of a small town, a proud mother 
showed off her newborn son. Upon noticing his lucky birthmark, townsfolk predicted 
he would marry a princess. But soon, these rumors reached the ears 
of the wicked king. Enraged, the king stole the child away, 
and sent him hurtling down the river. But the infant’s luck proved greater 
than the king’s plan. Years later, the king 
was traveling his realm, when he spotted a strapping young man 
with an uncanny birthmark. After confirming the child’s origins, the sly king entrusted the boy 
with a letter for the queen. The youth eagerly set out 
to deliver the message— not knowing he was carrying 
his own death sentence. That night, roaming bandits 
stumbled upon his camp. Yet when they read the brutal letter, 
they were filled with pity. Deciding to make trouble for the king 
instead, they scribbled a new note. As soon as the youth 
arrived at the palace, he locked eyes with the princess. The two felt destined for each other. And when the queen read 
that the king approved this union, she joyfully organized 
a whirlwind wedding. When the king returned, 
he was furious. But he couldn’t execute his daughter’s 
beloved without reason. So he devised a diabolical trial. He ordered the youth 
to travel to Hell itself, and return with three golden hairs 
freshly plucked from the Devil’s head. Only upon succeeding 
could he return to his bride. The youth searched across the land 
for the entrance to Hell, until he finally reached 
an eerie village. Here, he saw some villagers 
gathered around a well. They closed in on the youth, 
refusing to let him pass until he answered their question: 
why was the well dry? The youth replied, 
“I will answer when I return.” They directed him further into town, where he came across another set 
of villagers contemplating a gnarled tree. They refused to let him pass 
until he answered their question: why was the tree barren? Again, the youth responded, 
“I will answer when I return." These villagers guided him to the dock, 
where an elderly ferryman awaited. As he paddled through the black water, 
the ferryman rasped a third question: how can I escape my interminable task? Once more, the youth promised, 
“I will answer when I return.” At last, they reached a hut sinking 
into the swampy banks of Hell. Reluctantly, the youth knocked 
on the rotting door. The devil’s grandmother 
answered his call. She was known to help some visiting souls,
and harm others. The youth had just finished his story 
when they heard the devil’s footsteps. Without warning, 
the boy’s world appeared to shrink. The devil’s grandmother lifted him 
into the folds of her sleeve, and welcomed her grandson. The old woman set to work, 
lavishing the devil with food and drink. When he fell asleep, she deftly plucked 
three gleaming hairs from his head. With each plucked hair, the Devil briefly 
awoke and complained about his dreams, full of nearby villagers 
and their problems. The next morning, the youth departed— armed with three golden hairs, 
and three pieces of information. He shared the devil’s first dream 
with the ferryman. If the boatman could hand his oars 
to a willing passenger, he would be free from his task. Back at the village, the youth declared 
that there was a mouse gnawing at the root of the tree, 
and an enormous toad blocking the well. The villagers rewarded him handsomely 
for his help. Back from his journey, the youth thrust 
the devil’s hairs at the king— but his greedy father-in-law 
only had eyes for the gold. The sly youth told the king 
that even greater wealth awaited him across the river. Immediately, the king 
hastened to the riverbank. Eager to claim his riches, he held out his hands impatiently 
to the grinning ferryman— who happily handed over his oars.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Travel to hell and back, B. Marry a princess, C. Kill a king, D. Be rich beyond his wildest dreams
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the sun-dappled streets 
of a small town, a proud mother 
showed off her newborn son. Upon noticing his lucky birthmark, townsfolk predicted 
he would marry a princess. But soon, these rumors reached the ears 
of the wicked king. Enraged, the king stole the child away, 
and sent him hurtling down the river. But the infant’s luck proved greater 
than the king’s plan. Years later, the king 
was traveling his realm, when he spotted a strapping young man 
with an uncanny birthmark. After confirming the child’s origins, the sly king entrusted the boy 
with a letter for the queen. The youth eagerly set out 
to deliver the message— not knowing he was carrying 
his own death sentence. That night, roaming bandits 
stumbled upon his camp. Yet when they read the brutal letter, 
they were filled with pity. Deciding to make trouble for the king 
instead, they scribbled a new note. As soon as the youth 
arrived at the palace, he locked eyes with the princess. The two felt destined for each other. And when the queen read 
that the king approved this union, she joyfully organized 
a whirlwind wedding. When the king returned, 
he was furious. But he couldn’t execute his daughter’s 
beloved without reason. So he devised a diabolical trial. He ordered the youth 
to travel to Hell itself, and return with three golden hairs 
freshly plucked from the Devil’s head. Only upon succeeding 
could he return to his bride. The youth searched across the land 
for the entrance to Hell, until he finally reached 
an eerie village. Here, he saw some villagers 
gathered around a well. They closed in on the youth, 
refusing to let him pass until he answered their question: 
why was the well dry? The youth replied, 
“I will answer when I return.” They directed him further into town, where he came across another set 
of villagers contemplating a gnarled tree. They refused to let him pass 
until he answered their question: why was the tree barren? Again, the youth responded, 
“I will answer when I return." These villagers guided him to the dock, 
where an elderly ferryman awaited. As he paddled through the black water, 
the ferryman rasped a third question: how can I escape my interminable task? Once more, the youth promised, 
“I will answer when I return.” At last, they reached a hut sinking 
into the swampy banks of Hell. Reluctantly, the youth knocked 
on the rotting door. The devil’s grandmother 
answered his call. She was known to help some visiting souls,
and harm others. The youth had just finished his story 
when they heard the devil’s footsteps. Without warning, 
the boy’s world appeared to shrink. The devil’s grandmother lifted him 
into the folds of her sleeve, and welcomed her grandson. The old woman set to work, 
lavishing the devil with food and drink. When he fell asleep, she deftly plucked 
three gleaming hairs from his head. With each plucked hair, the Devil briefly 
awoke and complained about his dreams, full of nearby villagers 
and their problems. The next morning, the youth departed— armed with three golden hairs, 
and three pieces of information. He shared the devil’s first dream 
with the ferryman. If the boatman could hand his oars 
to a willing passenger, he would be free from his task. Back at the village, the youth declared 
that there was a mouse gnawing at the root of the tree, 
and an enormous toad blocking the well. The villagers rewarded him handsomely 
for his help. Back from his journey, the youth thrust 
the devil’s hairs at the king— but his greedy father-in-law 
only had eyes for the gold. The sly youth told the king 
that even greater wealth awaited him across the river. Immediately, the king 
hastened to the riverbank. Eager to claim his riches, he held out his hands impatiently 
to the grinning ferryman— who happily handed over his oars.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When the king learned that the baby was destined to take over the throne, he:
Options: A. Adopted the child, B. Sent orders for the child to be killed, C. Went to see the child for himself, D. Shut his daughter away
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What prediction did the townsfolk make about the newborn son's future when they saw his lucky birthmark? Options: A. He would become a great king., B. He would marry a princess., C. He would be very wealthy., D. He would have a short life. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the king's true intention when he entrusted the youth with a letter for the queen? Options: A. To inform the queen about the youth's origins., B. To ask the queen to arrange a wedding for the youth., C. To order the queen to execute the youth., D. To trick the youth into carrying his own death sentence. Correct Option: D
Question 3: How did the youth ultimately respond to the king's order to travel to Hell and return with three golden hairs from the Devil's head? Options: A. He refused to go and tried to negotiate with the king., B. He immediately traveled to Hell without any preparation., C. He set out to gather information and resources before embarking on the journey., D. The youth accepted the challenge and successfully completed the task with the help of the devil's grandmother. Correct Option: D
Question 4: What can be inferred about the devil's grandmother based on her actions in the story? Options: A. She is cruel and helps no one., B. She is kind and helps everyone., C. She is selective about who she helps and has her own motivations., D. She is unaware of the youth's intentions. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What purpose do the villagers serve in the youth's journey? Options: A. They provide the youth with material wealth and rewards., B. They serve as obstacles for the youth to overcome., C. They offer the youth guidance and advice., D. They pose questions that the youth must answer, leading him to gain knowledge and insight that ultimately helps him solve their problems. Correct Option: D
Question 6: How does the youth's response to the villagers' questions demonstrate his problem-solving skills? Options: A. He provides immediate answers to their questions., B. He refuses to answer their questions., C. He promises to answer their questions when he returns, showing that he is able to delay gratification and prioritize his goals., D. He asks for more information before answering their questions. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the significance of the devil's dreams in the story? Options: A. They serve as a distraction from the main plot., B. They provide insight into the devil's character., C. They offer solutions to the problems posed by the villagers., D. They have no impact on the story. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What motivates the king, and what are his strengths and weaknesses? Options: A. The king is motivated by a desire to protect his daughter and is a fair ruler., B. The king is motivated by greed and a desire for power, and is cunning but also impulsive and gullible., C. The king is motivated by a desire for justice and is a wise ruler., D. The king is motivated by a desire for revenge and is a ruthless ruler. Correct Option: B
Question 9: How does the youth's journey to Hell and back affect his character development? Options: A. The journey has no impact on the youth's character., B. The journey teaches the youth about the importance of wealth and power., C. The journey helps the youth develop problem-solving skills, gain confidence, and outwit his enemies., D. The journey serves as a test of the youth's courage and bravery. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What message do you think the story conveys about the nature of power and authority? Options: A. That those in power are always just and fair., B. That power and authority can be used for good or evil, and that individuals must be mindful of their actions., C. That those in power are always corrupt and abusive., D. That power and authority are irrelevant to individual success. Correct Option: B
Question 11: What was the ultimate fate of the king in the story? Options: A. He was punished for his cruel deeds., B. He was rewarded for his kindness., C. He was tricked by the youth and the ferryman, and ended up taking the ferryman's place as a result of his own greed., D. He remained in power and continued to rule with an iron fist. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although the ground truth MCQ and Question 2 do not have identical content, they both deal with the king's intentions and actions towards the youth. The ground truth MCQ asks about the king's reaction to the baby's predicted destiny, while Question 2 asks about the king's intention when entrusting the youth with a letter for the queen. 

However, both questions convey the king's malicious nature and his desire to eliminate the youth. The correct options in both questions (B in the ground truth MCQ and D in Question 2) highlight the king's cruel intentions.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the sun-dappled streets 
of a small town, a proud mother 
showed off her newborn son. Upon noticing his lucky birthmark, townsfolk predicted 
he would marry a princess. But soon, these rumors reached the ears 
of the wicked king. Enraged, the king stole the child away, 
and sent him hurtling down the river. But the infant’s luck proved greater 
than the king’s plan. Years later, the king 
was traveling his realm, when he spotted a strapping young man 
with an uncanny birthmark. After confirming the child’s origins, the sly king entrusted the boy 
with a letter for the queen. The youth eagerly set out 
to deliver the message— not knowing he was carrying 
his own death sentence. That night, roaming bandits 
stumbled upon his camp. Yet when they read the brutal letter, 
they were filled with pity. Deciding to make trouble for the king 
instead, they scribbled a new note. As soon as the youth 
arrived at the palace, he locked eyes with the princess. The two felt destined for each other. And when the queen read 
that the king approved this union, she joyfully organized 
a whirlwind wedding. When the king returned, 
he was furious. But he couldn’t execute his daughter’s 
beloved without reason. So he devised a diabolical trial. He ordered the youth 
to travel to Hell itself, and return with three golden hairs 
freshly plucked from the Devil’s head. Only upon succeeding 
could he return to his bride. The youth searched across the land 
for the entrance to Hell, until he finally reached 
an eerie village. Here, he saw some villagers 
gathered around a well. They closed in on the youth, 
refusing to let him pass until he answered their question: 
why was the well dry? The youth replied, 
“I will answer when I return.” They directed him further into town, where he came across another set 
of villagers contemplating a gnarled tree. They refused to let him pass 
until he answered their question: why was the tree barren? Again, the youth responded, 
“I will answer when I return." These villagers guided him to the dock, 
where an elderly ferryman awaited. As he paddled through the black water, 
the ferryman rasped a third question: how can I escape my interminable task? Once more, the youth promised, 
“I will answer when I return.” At last, they reached a hut sinking 
into the swampy banks of Hell. Reluctantly, the youth knocked 
on the rotting door. The devil’s grandmother 
answered his call. She was known to help some visiting souls,
and harm others. The youth had just finished his story 
when they heard the devil’s footsteps. Without warning, 
the boy’s world appeared to shrink. The devil’s grandmother lifted him 
into the folds of her sleeve, and welcomed her grandson. The old woman set to work, 
lavishing the devil with food and drink. When he fell asleep, she deftly plucked 
three gleaming hairs from his head. With each plucked hair, the Devil briefly 
awoke and complained about his dreams, full of nearby villagers 
and their problems. The next morning, the youth departed— armed with three golden hairs, 
and three pieces of information. He shared the devil’s first dream 
with the ferryman. If the boatman could hand his oars 
to a willing passenger, he would be free from his task. Back at the village, the youth declared 
that there was a mouse gnawing at the root of the tree, 
and an enormous toad blocking the well. The villagers rewarded him handsomely 
for his help. Back from his journey, the youth thrust 
the devil’s hairs at the king— but his greedy father-in-law 
only had eyes for the gold. The sly youth told the king 
that even greater wealth awaited him across the river. Immediately, the king 
hastened to the riverbank. Eager to claim his riches, he held out his hands impatiently 
to the grinning ferryman— who happily handed over his oars.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Years later, when the youth turned up at the palace:
Options: A. The king devised a quest to send him away, B. The king set him three tasks to complete in the castle, C. The king forbid him to see his daughter
Correct Option: A

In the sun-dappled streets 
of a small town, a proud mother 
showed off her newborn son. Upon noticing his lucky birthmark, townsfolk predicted 
he would marry a princess. But soon, these rumors reached the ears 
of the wicked king. Enraged, the king stole the child away, 
and sent him hurtling down the river. But the infant’s luck proved greater 
than the king’s plan. Years later, the king 
was traveling his realm, when he spotted a strapping young man 
with an uncanny birthmark. After confirming the child’s origins, the sly king entrusted the boy 
with a letter for the queen. The youth eagerly set out 
to deliver the message— not knowing he was carrying 
his own death sentence. That night, roaming bandits 
stumbled upon his camp. Yet when they read the brutal letter, 
they were filled with pity. Deciding to make trouble for the king 
instead, they scribbled a new note. As soon as the youth 
arrived at the palace, he locked eyes with the princess. The two felt destined for each other. And when the queen read 
that the king approved this union, she joyfully organized 
a whirlwind wedding. When the king returned, 
he was furious. But he couldn’t execute his daughter’s 
beloved without reason. So he devised a diabolical trial. He ordered the youth 
to travel to Hell itself, and return with three golden hairs 
freshly plucked from the Devil’s head. Only upon succeeding 
could he return to his bride. The youth searched across the land 
for the entrance to Hell, until he finally reached 
an eerie village. Here, he saw some villagers 
gathered around a well. They closed in on the youth, 
refusing to let him pass until he answered their question: 
why was the well dry? The youth replied, 
“I will answer when I return.” They directed him further into town, where he came across another set 
of villagers contemplating a gnarled tree. They refused to let him pass 
until he answered their question: why was the tree barren? Again, the youth responded, 
“I will answer when I return." These villagers guided him to the dock, 
where an elderly ferryman awaited. As he paddled through the black water, 
the ferryman rasped a third question: how can I escape my interminable task? Once more, the youth promised, 
“I will answer when I return.” At last, they reached a hut sinking 
into the swampy banks of Hell. Reluctantly, the youth knocked 
on the rotting door. The devil’s grandmother 
answered his call. She was known to help some visiting souls,
and harm others. The youth had just finished his story 
when they heard the devil’s footsteps. Without warning, 
the boy’s world appeared to shrink. The devil’s grandmother lifted him 
into the folds of her sleeve, and welcomed her grandson. The old woman set to work, 
lavishing the devil with food and drink. When he fell asleep, she deftly plucked

and three pieces of information. He shared the devil’s first dream 
with the ferryman. If the boatman could hand his oars 
to a willing passenger, he would be free from his task. Back at the village, the youth declared 
that there was a mouse gnawing at the root of the tree, 
and an enormous toad blocking the well. The villagers rewarded him handsomely 
for his help. Back from his journey, the youth thrust 
the devil’s hairs at the king— but his greedy father-in-law 
only had eyes for the gold. The sly youth told the king 
that even greater wealth awaited him across the river. Immediately, the king 
hastened to the riverbank. Eager to claim his riches, he held out his hands impatiently 
to the grinning ferryman— who happily handed over his oars.

**Transcript**:
In the sun-dappled streets 
of a small town, a proud mother 
showed off her newborn son. Upon noticing his lucky birthmark, townsfolk predicted 
he would marry a princess. But soon, these rumors reached the ears 
of the wicked king. Enraged, the king stole the child away, 
and sent him hurtling down the river. But the infant’s luck proved greater 
than the king’s plan. Years later, the king 
was traveling his realm, when he spotted a strapping young man 
with an uncanny birthmark. After confirming the child’s origins, the sly king entrusted the boy 
with a letter for the queen. The youth eagerly set out 
to deliver the message— not knowing he was carrying 
his own death sentence. That night, roaming bandits 
stumbled upon his camp. Yet when they read the brutal letter, 
they were filled with pity. Deciding to make trouble for the king 
instead, they scribbled a new note. As soon as the youth 
arrived at the palace, he locked eyes with the princess. The two felt destined for each other. And when the queen read 
that the king approved this union, she joyfully organized 
a whirlwind wedding. When the king returned, 
he was furious. But he couldn’t execute his daughter’s 
beloved without reason. So he devised a diabolical trial. He ordered the youth 
to travel to Hell itself, and return with three golden hairs 
freshly plucked from the Devil’s head. Only upon succeeding 
could he return to his bride. The youth searched across the land 
for the entrance to Hell, until he finally reached 
an eerie village. Here, he saw some villagers 
gathered around a well. They closed in on the youth, 
refusing to let him pass until he answered their question: 
why was the well dry? The youth replied, 
“I will answer when I return.” They directed him further into town, where he came across another set 
of villagers contemplating a gnarled tree. They refused to let him pass 
until he answered their question: why was the tree barren? Again, the youth responded, 
“I will answer when I return." These villagers guided him to the dock, 
where an elderly ferryman awaited. As he paddled through the black water, 
the ferryman rasped a third question: how can I escape my interminable task? Once more, the youth promised, 
“I will answer when I return.” At last, they reached a hut sinking 
into the swampy banks of Hell. Reluctantly, the youth knocked 
on the rotting door. The devil’s grandmother 
answered his call. She was known to help some visiting souls,
and harm others. The youth had just finished his story 
when they heard the devil’s footsteps. Without warning, 
the boy’s world appeared to shrink. The devil’s grandmother lifted him 
into the folds of her sleeve, and welcomed her grandson. The old woman set to work, 
lavishing the devil with food and drink. When he fell asleep, she deftly plucked 
three gleaming hairs from his head. With each plucked hair, the Devil briefly 
awoke and complained about his dreams, full of nearby villagers 
and their problems. The next morning, the youth departed— armed with three golden hairs, 
and three pieces of information. He shared the devil’s first dream 
with the ferryman. If the boatman could hand his oars 
to a willing passenger, he would be free from his task. Back at the village, the youth declared 
that there was a mouse gnawing at the root of the tree, 
and an enormous toad blocking the well. The villagers rewarded him handsomely 
for his help. Back from his journey, the youth thrust 
the devil’s hairs at the king— but his greedy father-in-law 
only had eyes for the gold. The sly youth told the king 
that even greater wealth awaited him across the river. Immediately, the king 
hastened to the riverbank. Eager to claim his riches, he held out his hands impatiently 
to the grinning ferryman— who happily handed over his oars.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: After visiting the devil's grandmother, the youth discovered that the village well was dry because
Options: A. there was an enormous toad blocking the well, B. of seasonal drought, C. the villagers over-consumed water
Correct Option: A
